noun.description: A type of liturgical hymn or troparion, sung during the morning and evening services in the Orthodox Church, typically in alternation with verses from the psalms.

origin: Mid 19th century; earliest use found in John Mason Neale (1818–1866), Church of England clergyman and author. From Byzantine Greek στιχηρόν versicle, use as noun (short for τροπάριον στιχηρόν troparion sung after a verse (or verses) of a psalm) of στιχηρός composed in verse, set out like poetry, in verses from ancient Greek στίχος line, verse + -ηρος, extended form of -ρος, suffix forming adjectives.
